text: 12oz can from Luckys Market in Clintonville: amber-brown pour, dingy white head. aroma of sweet toasty malt, toffee. tastes are caramel malt, little floral, background fruity. not a lot going on, but tasty overall.
Draft at source - pours reddish amber white head - nose/taste of pine, sap, resin, light fruity note - med body - dry finish
Draft - Light caramel. Deep dark Amber with a decent beige head. Caramel and touch of sweetness.

5/18/2016: Wow, this beer presents nicely with its deep copper-red color and lathery off-white head. Its malty, but not overly sweet, candy-like or plain sugary and thats a good thing. "Cookie dough" is actually and interesting and very applicable description. It also has some hits of ripened fruit, caramel, and bread crust. There isnt really any hop flavor and only a very light earthy-herbal bitterness to balance this beer. The beer has a medium to medium-full body and goes down so smoothly and even has a creamy mouthfeel/texture to it. I thoroughly enjoyed this pint and discovered that it went down very easily and very quickly! Draught at Ladder 19 in Cincinnati, Ohio.

Draft at Brass Tap from notes. Pours a hazy reddish amber color with a small off white head. The aroma and flavor have caramel malts, toasted malts, some earthy notes, mild fruit character, decent but nothing really stands out with this.

Sample at Red Brick as part of Ohio Brew Week. Hazy reddish-amber color with a medium off-white head that diminishes quickly to a wispy film. Small patches of lacing on the glass. Malt, caramel and slight hops in the nose. Light-bodied with a caramel malt character and mild earthy hops in the background. The finish is sweet with a malty aftertaste. Decent overall.
Draft pour. Clear copper color with a white head. The aroma has grain, smoke, and a bit of cookie dough. Medium sweetness and a touch of smoke. Medium body and moderate carbonation.

12oz sample bottle. Kind of a darker, hazy, red orange color, slight brown. Ring of sort of bubbly off-white head, leaving decent bits of lace. Medium body. Smooth, kind of crisp, lighter carbonation. Lightly dry finish. Good toasty malt, some mild fruit, light bit of smoke, caramel. Nice mild to moderate bitter taste, light sweet, more dry finish. Indeed, a nice balanced scottish style. Not too sweet.

Draft at The Brass Tap - U Square. Pours a cloudy amber color with a small off white head that leaves some lace. Notes of caramel and pale malts, earth, florals, and straw. Light-medium bodied, with moderate carbonation. Very straightforward, but good.

on tap @ Old Firehouse / Williamsburg OH --- Clear dark amber, off-white rim head, streaks of lace. Taste is malt that adds bootstrap molasses in the palate, then has carbonation and a little cedar in the swallow to provide a balanced finish. Reasonable, but there are better examples out there (and who said this is a Scottish Ale?)
Draft sample at brewpub pours light brownish amber. Nose caramel and toffee malt. Taste similar to nose with more apple fruit. Light bitter finish.

Draft sample. Poured dark reddish brown color with an fizzy off-white head that lasted with good lacing. Good complex sweet earthy toasted malt aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Good well balanced sweet earthy malt flavor with a medium dark sweet finish of moderate to long duration. Very good complex brew.

Draft: pours a very nice dark reddish color with a thin light tan head. Aromas are nice, toasted malt with a slight floral note to it. Taste has a nice caramel flavor the comes in as you work your way through the pint, and the hops balance it all out very well. Very enjoyable.
